meanings.definition: To rule or govern as a tyrant.
meanings.sent1: The king was tyrannising his subjects, making unfair laws and punishing anyone who disagreed.
meanings.sent2: The dictator was known for tyrannising the people, suppressing their freedoms and enforcing strict rules.
meanings.sent3: The teacher jokingly accused the class hamster of tyrannising the other pets in the classroom.
meanings.sent4: The storm was tyrannising the small town, causing destruction and chaos wherever it went.
meanings.sent5: The evil sorcerer was tyrannising the magical kingdom, spreading fear and darkness across the land.

meanings.definition: To exercise oppressive power or control over others.
meanings.sent1: The bully was tyrannising the younger students, making them do his homework and giving them no choice.
meanings.sent2: The corrupt government was tyrannising its citizens, restricting their rights and monitoring their every move.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous kitten seemed to be tyrannising the household dog, always stealing its toys and treats.
meanings.sent4: The giant corporation was tyrannising the small businesses, driving them out of the market with unfair practices.
meanings.sent5: The dark cloud was tyrannising the sunny sky, casting a shadow over the entire city.

meanings.definition: To act in a cruel or harsh manner towards others.
meanings.sent1: The mean boss was tyrannising his employees, constantly criticizing them and never appreciating their hard work.
meanings.sent2: The older sibling was tyrannising the younger ones, always teasing and picking on them without mercy.
meanings.sent3: The grumpy cat was tyrannising the friendly dog, swatting at it whenever it tried to play.
meanings.sent4: The relentless heatwave was tyrannising the farmers, drying up their crops and causing a severe drought.
meanings.sent5: The loud thunder was tyrannising the peaceful night, startling everyone awake with its powerful rumbling.
